author: Michelle Coffey
title: Banksy’s Dismaland will be repurposed to help shelter refugees in France
text:
As work began to dismantle Banksy’s Dismaland, the street artist said the materials used to create the dystopian theme park would be repurposed to help refugees in northern France.
“Coming soon: Dismaland Calais,” Banksy wrote in a post on Dismaland’s website, which featured a photograph of a migrant camp with a broken-down Disneyland-style castle superimposed in the background. “All the timber and fixtures from Dismaland are being sent to the ‘jungle’ refugee camp near Calais to build shelters.”
Dismaland Banksy plants a decaying Cinderella castle in the middle of a migrant camp in Calais in this photo from Dismaland’s website. Dismaland, an art show “experiment” featuring new works by Banksy and others, was a sellout, drawing 150,000 visitors and bringing roughly $30 million to the small English town of Weston-super-Mare, according to the Associated Press .
See also: Banksy’s dystopian theme park is a dark twist on Disneyland
Banksy’s work is often loaded with social and political commentary on topics such as greed and poverty, absurdity and alienation. With Dismaland, Banksy explored inequality. One exhibit featured tiny remote-controlled boats crowded with refugees in a polluted pond. The boats were designed to be almost impossible to navigate, Banksy said in an interview posted on the Dismaland website. The boats would randomly switch to ensure that visitors steering them had “no control over whether [their] destiny is to be an asylum seeker or a Western superpower.”
The migrant crisis in Calais has grown over the summer, with thousands of immigrants, mainly from Sudan, Eritrea, Ethiopia and Afghanistan, living in makeshift camps and shelters in an area near the port referred to as “the jungle.” The number of migrants camping there hit a new high recently with many hoping to cross the English Channel to reach the United Kingdom.
